info.game_comments:
Trevor Norris game 4.

(Cheryl: Hi, I'm Cheryl of the Clue Crew.  You wouldn't believe where I have sand after taping clues for Jeopardy!--next.)

(2, 1).clue: A shady corner is the perfect spot for this type of plant that includes thousands of species

(3, 1).clue: This author of "The Red Badge of Courage" based his story "The Open Boat" on his own experience after a shipwreck

(4, 1).clue: We told you this film was called "Hot Babes" in Taiwan; in France, it was "Charlie and the Funny Women"

(5, 1).clue: Or would you rather be one of these? (a cross between a male donkey & a female horse)

(6, 1).clue: In our opinion, it's a newspaper article that represents the publisher's point of view

(2, 2).clue: Stems & leaves used to propagate new plants, or a British term for newspaper clippings

(3, 2).clue: This "French Connection" actor co-authored the 1999 novel "Wake of the Perdido Star"

(4, 2).clue: C'mon; 1993 Taiwanese title "Who Freed the Super Whale"...what more do you need?

(5, 2).clue: A record one of these from an African elephant weighed 236 pounds & was over 11 feet long

(6, 2).clue: At least the Antarctic range named for this Henry Ford descendant isn't considered a failure

(2, 3).clue: Deal with certain plants before they spread; or in rhyme, "One year seeding means seven years" this

(3, 3).clue: This story of a defecting Soviet sub captain was the first novel from both Tom Clancy & Naval Institute Press

(4, 3).clue: In Japan this 2000 Cameron Crowe film was known as "Those Days with Penny Lane"

(5, 3).clue: This very small place in Ohio was named after P.T. Barnum's very big elephant

(6, 3).clue: Hell-oooo, possums, "She's" the international star who took a "Royal Tour" in 2001

(2, 4).clue: These roses are so named because their scent resembles a plant used to brew a hot beverage

(3, 4).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew is at the beach.)  The birds remind me of this 1970 book by former Air Force pilot Richard Bach

(4, 4).clue: In Taiwan this 1998 sequel to "The Fugitive" was known as "Execution with No Reasons"

(5, 4).clue: The tales of this elephant & his family were created by the Brunhoff family

(6, 4).clue: This place, whose name means "place of pleasure", is often thought to have been in Mesopotamia

(2, 5).clue: From the Greek topos, which means "place", it's the type of plant cultivation seen here

(3, 5).clue: In a 1976 Clive Cussler novel, Dirk Pitt wants to raise this ship to recover a store of byzanium, a rare element

(4, 5).clue: In Taiwan "You're Still Next" was this horror film's sequel; Pop Rocks killing Life cereal's Mikey is an example of one

(5, 5).clue: Cartoonist who gave the Democrats the donkey & the Republicans the elephant

(6, 5).clue: This city's name derives from the Celtic word meaning "Eiden's Fort"

(1, 1).clue: He led Israel's army in the 1967 Six-Day War & was assassinated as prime minister in 1995

(2, 1).clue: Fishy name for light pink with a yellowish tinge

(3, 1).clue: The pons, meaning "bridge", connects the medulla to higher parts of this organ

(4, 1).clue: In 2001 he revealed that after reaching the summit May 29, 1953 he left everything there & ran back down to camp

(5, 1).clue: "Emma", "Sliding Doors" -- her English-accented films just keep on coming

(6, 1).clue: After a formal dinner, place this loosely next to your plate, not on your chair

(1, 2).clue: Seen here, he "hacked" plenty of on & off-screen adventure into his life; 1909 to 1959

(2, 2).clue: In Esperanto this day of the week is Vendredo

(3, 2).clue: The hormone oxytocin stimulates the uterus &, soon after, these milk-producing glands

(4, 2).clue: Reinhold Messner amazed people when he reached the summit without a bottle of this, a need for most

(5, 2).clue: A BBC review said as Bert in "Mary Poppins" he "speaks a form of Cockney unknown within 5,000 miles of Bow Bells"

(6, 2).clue: If a girl receives one of these small bouquets on prom night, she must wear it no matter how much it clashes

(1, 3).clue: He bought out the McDonald burger-making brothers in 1961 for $2.7 million

(2, 3).clue: It's discrimination against & stereotyping of older people

(3, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew demonstrates her wrist.) The ----- in your wrist when you extend your thumb is an anatomical this, a container for powdered tobacco

(4, 3).clue: In 1996 Greg MacGillivray produced a film on the world's tallest mountain for this big-screen format

(5, 3).clue: When she played Anna in 1999 & met the king of Siam, she was sporting a British accent

(6, 3).clue: At a weddng reception, he traditionally proposes the first toast

(1, 4).clue: This clubfooted Nazi propagandist was born in Rheydt in 1897 & died in 1945

(2, 4).clue: In slang, they're the 5-0 or the Po-Po's

(3, 4).clue: When food enters the small intestine, it's joined there by this fluid stored in the gallbladder

(4, 4).clue: Yuichiro Miura, set to climb Everest after he turns 70 in 2003, has done this down each continent's highest peak

(5, 4).clue: This North Carolina-born "Hannibal" actress donned an English accent for "An Ideal Husband"

(6, 4).clue: Eat this vegetable leaf by leaf with your fingers, but when you get to the heart, use a knife & fork

(1, 5).clue: Because she died at 39 in 1964, this Southerner only wrote "Wise Blood" & one other novel

(2, 5).clue: Used on citrus fruits, it's the item seen here

(3, 5).clue: It's the more spacey term for the eye socket

(4, 5).clue: Ang Tsering Sherpa, who turned 98 in 2001, was on this man's 1924 expedition -- "Because it's there"

(5, 5).clue: His Ned Alleyn in "Shakespeare in Love" was a far cry from his role in "Armageddon"

(6, 5).clue: At a party, serve champagne in these tall, slender glasses; it'll stay bubbly longer

(0, 0).clue: Invented by Dan Robbins, this product was first sold in the 1950s with the slogan "Every Man a Rembrandt"
